thread.title: Parents are poor judges of their children's happiness
thread.title_full: Parents are poor judges of their children's happiness | afr.com

author: Jill Margo
title: Parents are poor judges of their children's happiness
text:
Parents often misjudge their children's emotional states. iStock Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Jill Margo Parents' estimation of their children's happiness differs significantly from the child's own assessment of their feelings, according to a new study.
While parents of 10- and 11-year-olds consistently overestimated their child's happiness, those with 15- and 16-year-olds underestimate it.
Published in the Journal of Experimental Child Psychology , the study showed parents were inclined to score their offspring's happiness closely in line with their own feelings.
This "egocentric bias" caused them to rely too heavily on their own feelings in assessing the happiness of the family unit as a whole.
The study involved 357 children and adolescents from two different schools in Spain along with their parents.
While both age groups expressed similar levels of happiness, there was a decline in the level of happiness in parents of adolescents.
An inability to read their children's happiness appropriately can increase misunderstanding and render parents less able to provide appropriate emotional support.
